reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is great just from my first few hours playing it, from what ive seen there arnt really to many bugs. you will like this game of you like LoL (Leauge of Legends), because it combines an RTS game with a third pearson commander/leader unit that you play as. Some may say the game is a little bit micro transaction heavy, but with the all the content thats okay, and you can get most of what you need by buying the starter pack,(REALLY GOOD DEAL) for only $10, witch I think is very reasonable. Some might not like the graphics but I would rather have decent graphics and lots of content, than amazing graphics and a game with only 4 maps, that you have to pay another $60 for for more content that should have been in it the first place. My only real problem with the game is it takes a while to find ranked miltiplayer games but that will change when it grows a little more.
Over All: 9/10

This however, was a disappointment. The menu was a tad confusing and the tutorial was flat out not needed but was locked in. Don't pick up this game if you're looking for something great, maybe Hawken is a better choice but if you're looking for something to master and you're extremely bored maybe try it out, if not, don't even bother. 3.5/10

reviewText:
Product received for free

Early Access Review

This game is awesome, as long as you remember that it is in Beta...
There have been several updates (eg: Auto Deploy Arm) that have caused the playerbase to fall from time to time, but these changes - even those you may not like - are a part of playing a Beta state game.

Some Great things about the game itself:
- Dota meets RTS (with prebuilt buildings to capture/deploy from).
- Massive Unit list to fully customise your loadout (from Infantry to Tanks to Artillery/Turrets and Support).
- Increasing list of Parts to customise your AirMech performance with.
- Pilots and Items to enhance your play style.
- CO-OP & PVP Leaderboards for weekly prizes.
- Simply an insane amout of purely cosmetic" flair and pets to show off your personal Style (obtainable with premium "Diamonds" currency
date:
generally bought with real cash).
- Seasonal Promotions in the Shop.
- Player Market.
- A Basecamp to build
recommended:
with crops to generate free "Kudos" - also earnt just by playing (free ingame currency).
- Nanoforge (the crafting craze continues in AirMech...).
- All critical gameplay Units & AirMechs obtainable with Kudos.

Some Great things about the Community in AirMech:
- Helpful & Friendly.
- MODS keep faction chat in check (Plus the ingame Swear Filter option helps).
- Diamond Rolls (sponsored by players) share Diamonds via a Chat minigame - Click those Dice! Highest and lowest numbers win Diamonds!
- Factions help newer ones to learn the game
I am the Leader of "[Rise]" Faction
hoursPlayed: contact me ingame for an invite to [Rise]
voteText: there i am known as Dartis.\nSome Factions also have Joining requirements
helpfulPercent: something to strive for.\n- For those that sign up to the Forums
votesHelpful:
there are Giveaways hosted by Generous AirMech Members and Players.

Some things new players confront when just starting:
- Diamonds! As said
votesTotal: these are the Premium currency obtainable with real money (generally).\n- Market. There are Distinctive benefits (like reduced Tax) for those that are at least Silver VIP ($5USD) over those that are unable to (or choose not to). This makes selling on the Market (and earning those precious Diamonds) harder for those F2P'ers (however this isn't necassary to play or be good at the game itself).\n- Kudos. Even though you will gradually earn Kudos
votesFunny: some players find it takes too long to buy everything they need to play (but please don't spend your early Diamonds on these things
commentsCount: you may regret it later).\n- PVP. Ranked PVP doesnt allow Parts or Ultimates but Unranked PVP does. This has led to some believing AirMech is now P2W as Ultimates are only available with Diamonds. However Ultimates were 'nerfed' a few patches back and are not as OP as they used to be
column16: they now only give an advantage. As an incentive
column17: "Honor" was released for those who play PVP Without Ultimates against those that Do - earn enough Honor and you'll unlock some exclusive stuff...\n\nOverall
column18: I love Airmech. Between playing CO-OP
column23:
Diamond Rolls (or the Ever OP "Black Diamond Roll") there is enough content here to have kept me entertained for years! Just remember its a Beta state game and so will you!

Sign Up through this Link to recieve an additional 1000 Kudos to get started with!
http://airme.ch/1BhNmCi"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's a good game for single player but the multiplayer is completely unplayable. Their servers are absolute ♥♥♥♥♥ (unless games are hosted by player's clients, which would make a lot of sense). Constantly being killed when far out of range of enemy weapons, invisible missiles, game freezing during due to lag, I was kicked no less than three times because of 'connectivity issues' which were completely out of my hands. Just a joke, especially when my net speed is 30 up/4 down with a constant 20-30 ping. Get your ♥♥♥♥ together, Carbon. I should not be lagging this badly.

The hey buy stuff" messages that are constantly shoved in your face leave a bad taste in my mouth
date: but they have to make money somehow I guess. Maybe they'll eventually be able to afford semi-decent server infrastructure one day. I would like to state that I firmly believe that the server issues are the game's only problem aside from balance issues in low level PvP; that is to say
recommended: you can't get some units below a specific level - most notably the Goliath
hoursPlayed: which is level 7 and wrecked me several times because I had no answer (the Buster did some work
voteText: but it's just not enough).\n\nI understand that the game is early access
helpfulPercent: but it's been in development for almost THREE YEARS. This is not acceptable for a game in this situation
votesHelpful:
especially when they constantly throw "buy this and you could have all this cool stuff! Just £20!" messages in your face.

Conclusion / TL;DR
All in all the game is built fundamentally around multiplayer and that's a shame
votesTotal: because the multiplayer is completely unplayable due to server issues. It's hard to get into because you'll get stomped by people with units you can't buy
votesFunny: but the singleplayer could be thoroughly enjoyable if the bots weren't utterly brain dead. It's free so certainly try it out with friends
commentsCount: but my final verdict is that you should just save your time and play free games without crippling server issues."

I tried this game for a couple hours.  It's immediately engaging, and nice to look at.  If you're into twitch-style shooter games, this could be a step up for you as compared to other more traditional MOBAs.  However, it's far, far too ambitious for me to enjoy.

You start off learning a bit about your Airmech and how to manipulate the minion" units under your command.  At this point I'd say the interface and the ability to affect the game could just stop
date: and remain perfectly enjoyable.  Just being able to transform and fly around in the middle of a large-scale conflict
hoursPlayed: and the novelty of the control system would make an enjoyable game.  Unfortunately your responsibilities don't stop there
voteText: by any means.\n\nNext you find out that you can produce units
helpfulPercent: that indeed you need to on a constant basis
votesHelpful: while managing credits and the time it takes to build them.  You must select units other than infantry by flying over them while holding a key and give them more explicit orders with other keys.  You use the function keys to create upgrades for your Airmech
votesTotal: which are extremely varied and a bit confusing in how they work at the outset.  Meanwhile you are trying to attack enemy Airmechs who scream out of the air at you from close off-screen
votesFunny: manage your territory
commentsCount: pick up your own units with another key that is unreliable at best
column16: transform and use special attacks when needed.\n\nI'd compare this game to a side-scrolling shooter combined with a turn-based board game or an RTS.  There is of course a learning curve and I'm sure a high degree of expertise can be gained in it
column17: but the end product is both too demanding and too frenetic to be very appealing to either specific crowd.  I'd have been quite happier if they toned it down a notch and decided to stick more with one or the other."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Addiction in a small 400mb package that comes at no extra cost aside from the massive amount of time you will probably spend playing it.

Fun 1 v 1 or 2 v 2 or 3 v 3 level designs similar to starcraft combined with desert strike style gameplay along with a robotech / macross / battletech style land air mech.

There is even a single player skirmish survival and co-op if your'e tired of competition and a fairly deep unit design system allowing for lots of diversity in tactics.

If you enjoy games like starcraft but want even more challenge due to controlling your units + commanding your units, then try this one on for size you have nothin to lose!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Awesome game!
If you're into RTS or shooters this satisfies both needs.  Unlike most RTS games you can actually fight alongside your units, not to mention transport them-key feature, I love this game because of it.  The community is also a boss and really helpful, and you can go so many different routes with playing styles.  And there's no worry about this being a pay2win game because even if you play against someone with diamond/gold/silver VIP or Airmech Prime the devs focus on balancing it out for the players who don't buy any boosters/DLC! Not to mention the developers are very active in the community, which again, is awesome.  Overall this game is awesome, and you should take my referral[airme.ch] if this intrigued you!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

AirMech is an intriguing attempt at a fusion of moba/action games, with a small hint of rts. The game plays well, and while not inherently intuitive, the controls are well designed, and the games overall pacing is great.

Although currently in Beta, the game over the last year+ has grown and improved, showing a dedication from the developers, and loyalty to the playerbase. As of right now, I have high hopes for the game, and am excited to see exactly what unfolds as the curtain of the official release rises.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Free to play, the words that make many people think pure grind-fest, pay to win aspects and generally commitment to playing constantly. While there are bonuses to perks, the thing I love is that most of the items you can purchase with premium money, you can get by winning battles. In addition, all the Over Powered items is restricted. Wait, this isn't a pay to win? I don't really think so. From what I have seen of the premium and VIP shop, it's actually very balanced. Those who do pay with real money get a slighter advantage, but not by much. Alrighty, we got the worst aspect of the game out, let's dive right into this with swords a slicing, is this worth the time? Surely, this early access game is horrible, you say! Look at all the other EA games that have scarred our wallets with promises of updates.

Fear not, for this game is a gem which I highly recommend to anyone who is a StarCraft fan, RTS lover, or just love shooting the crud out of the other team. Now you might be asking why would you love this if you are a StarCraft fan, this game doesn't even resemble that Blizzard gem most people know and love. Actually, the art style of this game reminds me of that, very bold, isometric, and has units you can immediately relate to. In addition, another cool feature is that you have an upkeep, a maximum number of units on the field at any given time. As you capture more outposts, that number increases, if they get captured, it lowers thus making it a hectic scramble to try and take control of them as fast as possible. That's about as far as that goes, but if you are a die-hard fan of Command & Conquer, I suggest you try this out right now.

Piloting the mech is actually very responsive. I point to shoot, it aims and kills. The speed of each game will have you thinking fast, moving from point to point, constantly responding to attacks. The difficulty curve of the game is slightly flat, but the customization of the game is just massive! You get to pilot one of several mechs, ranging from space ships and flying saucers to bombers and fighter jets. I guarantee that you will pick the game up thinking about spending 10 minutes in one match, then find yourself playing for hours.

There are a few problems that I see with this game and one of them is the graphics. When you open up the game, it is in windowed mode which is nice, but I'm usually afraid of clicking out of the game while in battle which might cost me. Putting it in full screen, I immediately regret that. Everything becomes fuzzy and distorted, making the text hard to read and the gameplay a bit annoying. This is not game-breaking, but you will be deciding which you would prefer, having the small screen or going full screen. Another thing that bothers me is that navigation is a slight problem. Everything is easy to find, but the problem lies in the layout. As you go through, it's a mixture of large tabs, small tabs, intermixed sized tabs, and buttons.

Other than those minor problems, this game is extremely fun to play. It will take a while to get use to the controls and field of play, but once you learn how to transform and move your units from point A to point B, you will be strategizing to take the next outpost. The gameplay is very solid, there are a ton of quests for you to do and challenges if you want to sharpen your skill. For an Early Access game, this is a highly refined and very addictive game.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nAirmech. This game is so unique. The graphics are cartoony and rich. The Transformer feel of the game is just so cool. It is a mix between Starcraft and DotA! YES! Both MLG games put into one uniquely brewed game. The game has a smooth approach with balancing four main things, money, power, outposts, and your base. You have to make sure you have enough money to supply your units, enough power to build more, make sure you have outposts to add more power or money generators and make sure your base is secure. If the game is played right (Cap all out posts[NO♥♥♥♥INGRUSHING♥♥♥♥♥♥♥S]) you will have a blast with friends, or meet some new ones. This game mixes strategy with casual action. I love it and it is better that it is F2P. Pick this up now. If you like it, support the devs by buying some booster packs.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Not a hardcore MOBA player by any means.  I do play RTS games a bit though.  This game feels like a nice combination between the too.  It's a bit streamlined, perhaps more than I'd personally like, but definitely not enough to keep the game from being enjoyable.

AirMech, as the name suggests, has you controlling a machine that can transform between an airship and mech.  While in airship mode you can deploy units which you can queue up to build at any time during the game.  With mech (ground) mode mostly being just for combat.  However certain AirMechs do offer some additional perks to being either on the ground or in the air, such as an aura buff for your troops while in mech mode, or a weapon that can fire both at air and ground units.

All AirMechs are in fact available and relatively easy to obtain for free, as well as the vast majority of PvP-enabled deployable Units.  The balancing of player-controlled AirMechs seems pretty solid, as does the balance of most Units you command.

Currently the game offers solo play and cooperative play (Only 90 minutes of it per day will earn you XP/Currency unless you make at least one purchase).  There is PvP as well, of course, and that is really the focus of this game as it is with any other MOBA, though if you're more casual, you might still enjoy the PvE elements as well.

Overall I'd say it's a great game for both the casual player who's into the RTS and MOBA style of the game for the PvE elements and the hardcore player who's in it for the PvP elements.  Free to play with lack of a real Pay2Win, a very high value per dollar when you do actually spend money, and a game that runs well on almost any PC.  If you've read this far, just stop and go try it for yourself, you won't be disappointed.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This was a very suprising game for me. I was not expecting much, because I thought it was either a MOBA or a brawler, neither of which I am a fan of. But, it was free, so I decided to download it. It well surpassed my expectations. It's more on the MOBA side but better than the other ones out there. It is fast paced with the units having almost as much power as the airmechs, or the hero character similar to other MOBAs. There is just so much potential to this game. There are many customizable options and it isn't a pay to win kind of game. It's definitly worth the download so far

The only things that I believe should be added are the following (it's still in early access, so i'm not too worried)
-The lack of maps
-Most of the maps are extremely similar according to the layout.
-Some connections issues (i.e. latency, even though we have extremely new internet equipment [router, motem, all that jazz]).
-CTF mode has yet to function (at least as far as I can tell)

And that's all the issues I can come up with. For an early access game, that's not bad.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you've ever played MOBA games before, you know they can be fast and furious; add in the ability to run around the battlefield in a transforming mech and things get even more crazy.  In effect the game plays like Herzog Zwei, from back in the Sega Genesis days; your mech has to pick up and deploy units to areas they are needed.

For being an early access game this is certainly well polished, and i can honestly say i'm wondering what the campaign mode is going to be like in the future.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is essentially a modernized Herzog Zwei. Chances are you don't know what that is. HZ was one of the best underrated games for the Genesis, and way ahead of its time. It was arguably the first RTS, predating even Dune II. But enough history, just what the hell is this game?

Imagine Smash TV except that you are flying and in a much bigger map. You're trying to destroy the opponent's base, and to help you do that, you purchase and deploy units as a flying transport with guns. But that's not all! Your flying transport can transform into a giant robot and can attack enemy ground forces, letting you directly participate in the action instead of sitting around micromanaging bases. If you die, you undergo a rez timer, losing precious time to fend off the inevitable advance.

Their servers are... okay. If someone's ping gets even moderately high, the game chugs and a vote pops up. Not cool.

For all its good points, the game is still incomplete, being in active beta. There's no combat music (yet). This is a shame because HZ actually had really good music, by the same person who did Thunderforce. Hopefully their musican will do justice.

Furthermore, this game has NO STORY whatsoever. Even HZ had... an intro and an ending, with a manual adding slightly more detail. HZ also had a single player campaign, which is what I spent most of my time on back then. Airmech has none of that. Sure you can play maps solo and earn in-game credits, but there doesn't feel like any goal or ending in sight.

But why not just go ahead and give it a try? The game is very much free to play, funded with microtransactions. There's only a handful of things you can't obtain without cash, and even then most of those cash items won't turn the tide for you.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you like Dota and you like robots, then this is the game for you!

This game is more interactive than other strategic games; this one puts you on the spot to build, defend, and/or destroy.
So far, this game offers skirmish battles for up to 6 players, which is split into two teams. Each team builds units to defend their fortress or attack opposing team's fortress. You can have your AirMech play the role of support, or you can use it to aid your offensive line. There is quite a selection of unit loadouts, AirMechs, and even upgrades to choose from. So far, there are a number of quests and a few challenges to keep you busy for a while.

If you don't think that's a lot, don't worry; the game is still in beta, so there is still more to come.

The best part of all: it's free. You can still enjoy most of the features of the game normally, but if you want more, just buy anything with a purchase of at least $9.99 USD, or buy AirMech Prime. And yes, the game has some purchase sales on occasion, so it would be a good idea to be on the lookout for that.

Try the game, I'd bet you'll like it. I sure do; I would certainly put some of my money on this game... if I had any that is. =)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

AirMech is a game that has a lot of potential. An Action Real Time Strategy game featuring transforming mechs, customizable loadouts with tons of different units? Sounds like a dream game.

The question is, is it a realistic dream? I think it is.

Let me start by saying AirMech has a very small playerbase right now compared to other Free to Play online games. This is not necessarily a bad thing, as the game is still fun when played versus bots.

The game has a bit of Pay to Win by having items be unlocked exclusively with in-game currency that can be purchase with real-life money, but the in-game currency is acquired at a pretty decent amount so you'll find yourself being able to buy two or three new units or a new pilot. The only thing you'll really find yourself grinding for is the ability to customize a mech, but all of the mechs are available at start to play as, just not to customize.

The gameplay is fun and fast paced and heavily strategy based. Based on which mech you use you'll find yourself playing the game quite differently. My personal favorite mech is the UFO, which has so little outgoing damage and so little damage reduction I don't even bother shooting most of the time. The fact that the games are exclusively 2v2 is understandable given the small playerbase, but it makes for a less action packed game than it could be for people who play as more strategy heavy mechs than pew pew heavy mechs.

The game has a lot of growing room, and I see it becoming very big if the game adjusts some of its.... Commercialistic... Aspects.

I personally don't mind that the game has a lot of things on sale, but it's a LOT of things on sale, and you're going to be flooded with them the moment you load up the game. If I want to buy something, I will, I promise, but honestly having giant ads for your in-game items flash before my eyes right when I load the game makes me not want to buy them.

The game is being constantly updated, though it seems that a lot of the updates are for things you have to buy. For a game in Beta, I feel this needs to be changed. Yeah, I understand that you need to put food on the table, but you're in the business of making a video game, which is also the business of making money. If your game is fun, and people enjoy it, the players will come and the money will flow in.

All in all, as it stands, I give AirMech a nice little 7/10. It's above average. It has a lot of potential it needs to expand on, and it has a bit of a money hungry attitude it needs to tone down on. Gameplay wise it's a fantastic Free to Play game that rewards the player for being good at the game. If you're considering giving it a try, there's no reason not to.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is not an easy game to fit into one static category like rts or MOBA, in fact it's kind of a mixture of both.I have a background in both genres, I play alot of Age of Empires and League of Legends, so I understand the mechanics that go into games like those. When I play this game it feels like the perfect balance in controls and it is really easy to learn. In game you are basically a transformer with the ability to fly, pick up troops, build an army, and destroy other airmechs. The goal of every match is to capture a base, build armies to capture other bases, and then take out the enemies base.

Now even though I said the controls were near perfect and I generally enjoy the game but it isn't without faults. The game looks as if it takes alot of strategy to succeed at but that just isn't the case. Every match I play nowadays consist of both teams building moneymakers (structures that give the player resources to build soldiers) and then sending an army to the middle of the map where a major base is. If the base is taken then the game is basically over at that point because it is such a strong chokepoint that becomes impenetrable. Once that base is taken then another army is sent to the base of their enemy and the game ends. This flaw in game design makes it that every game is basically the same and if you lose the middle base then your game is over and you might as well sit back and watch.

I am still recommending this game because it is not completed and there is a chance that the developers will change the layout of each map so that their is no stronghold in the middle that ends the game once taken. I am convinced that if that error is fixed then this game will become one of my new favourites.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is essentially a modernized Herzog Zwei. Chances are you don't know what that is. HZ was one of the best underrated games for the Genesis, and way ahead of its time. It was arguably the first RTS, predating even Dune II. But enough history, just what the hell is this game?

Imagine Smash TV except that you are flying and in a much bigger map. You're trying to destroy the opponent's base, and to help you do that, you purchase and deploy units as a flying transport with guns. But that's not all! Your flying transport can transform into a giant robot and can attack enemy ground forces, letting you directly participate in the action instead of sitting around micromanaging bases. If you die, you undergo a rez timer, losing precious time to fend off the inevitable advance.

Their servers are... okay. If someone's ping gets even moderately high, the game chugs and a vote pops up. Not cool.

For all its good points, the game is still incomplete, being in active beta. There's no combat music (yet). This is a shame because HZ actually had really good music, by the same person who did Thunderforce. Hopefully their musican will do justice.

Furthermore, this game has NO STORY whatsoever. Even HZ had... an intro and an ending, with a manual adding slightly more detail. HZ also had a single player campaign, which is what I spent most of my time on back then. Airmech has none of that. Sure you can play maps solo and earn in-game credits, but there doesn't feel like any goal or ending in sight.

But why not just go ahead and give it a try? The game is very much free to play, funded with microtransactions. There's only a handful of things you can't obtain without cash, and even then most of those cash items won't turn the tide for you.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nAirmech. This game is so unique. The graphics are cartoony and rich. The Transformer feel of the game is just so cool. It is a mix between Starcraft and DotA! YES! Both MLG games put into one uniquely brewed game. The game has a smooth approach with balancing four main things, money, power, outposts, and your base. You have to make sure you have enough money to supply your units, enough power to build more, make sure you have outposts to add more power or money generators and make sure your base is secure. If the game is played right (Cap all out posts[NO♥♥♥♥INGRUSHING♥♥♥♥♥♥♥S]) you will have a blast with friends, or meet some new ones. This game mixes strategy with casual action. I love it and it is better that it is F2P. Pick this up now. If you like it, support the devs by buying some booster packs.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

You like MOBA games but tired of the same map? Or tired that your creeps are just annoyingly stupid?
Try this half strategy half rpg game, you can fully customize your mecha with cosmetics and equipment to improve its strenght.
Of course as it's a free to play game it has to have the premium part, but it's not a pay to win game, so even if you have the 'ultra' version of some units, you can't use them on pvp.
But the vip version offers a hugue ammount of skins for your mech and that makes it speccially attractive.
You can play PVP as you wish but not everybody is so brave, so you have a pve combat system, to beat the nasty npc with your friends.

If there's something I could complain, is that there are not very much maps, units or team colours. Also the max player cap is 4 in a 2vs2 pvp match. But that's just the beginning of this game. They will update it and more things are up to come.

As it's free to play, I would invite everybody to join this amazing game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Not a hardcore MOBA player by any means.  I do play RTS games a bit though.  This game feels like a nice combination between the too.  It's a bit streamlined, perhaps more than I'd personally like, but definitely not enough to keep the game from being enjoyable.

AirMech, as the name suggests, has you controlling a machine that can transform between an airship and mech.  While in airship mode you can deploy units which you can queue up to build at any time during the game.  With mech (ground) mode mostly being just for combat.  However certain AirMechs do offer some additional perks to being either on the ground or in the air, such as an aura buff for your troops while in mech mode, or a weapon that can fire both at air and ground units.

All AirMechs are in fact available and relatively easy to obtain for free, as well as the vast majority of PvP-enabled deployable Units.  The balancing of player-controlled AirMechs seems pretty solid, as does the balance of most Units you command.

Currently the game offers solo play and cooperative play (Only 90 minutes of it per day will earn you XP/Currency unless you make at least one purchase).  There is PvP as well, of course, and that is really the focus of this game as it is with any other MOBA, though if you're more casual, you might still enjoy the PvE elements as well.

Overall I'd say it's a great game for both the casual player who's into the RTS and MOBA style of the game for the PvE elements and the hardcore player who's in it for the PvP elements.  Free to play with lack of a real Pay2Win, a very high value per dollar when you do actually spend money, and a game that runs well on almost any PC.  If you've read this far, just stop and go try it for yourself, you won't be disappointed.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

OK, i usually don't prefer strategy games so i didn't know what to expect from this game, When i started it all i had to do was make a usernaame so i did. When it was done loaded i played the tutorial and then started single-player 1v1 mode. After winning my reward was 136 kudos (in-game currency) and 112 XP.

This game has a very unique leveling, there are three level systems, your mech, player and in-game.
When you level up in-game you can buy special abilities/attacks for your mech. When you level up you unlock more powerful (and exspensive) units.

This game is NOT a p2w (pay to win) Dimonds the money bought currency is only used to buy cosmetics and legendary pilots and you CAN buy units with dimonds.

You fight along side your troops on the battefield.

Multiple Modes:
Single-player
Coop
pvp
Story mode coming soon (Only for PRIME owners)
Survival mode (online and off)


Amazing transformer-like mechs. There are a lot of them, just to name a few:
Striker- The fist mech you start out with, suprisingly AWESOME.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is not an easy game to fit into one static category like rts or MOBA, in fact it's kind of a mixture of both.I have a background in both genres, I play alot of Age of Empires and League of Legends, so I understand the mechanics that go into games like those. When I play this game it feels like the perfect balance in controls and it is really easy to learn. In game you are basically a transformer with the ability to fly, pick up troops, build an army, and destroy other airmechs. The goal of every match is to capture a base, build armies to capture other bases, and then take out the enemies base.

Now even though I said the controls were near perfect and I generally enjoy the game but it isn't without faults. The game looks as if it takes alot of strategy to succeed at but that just isn't the case. Every match I play nowadays consist of both teams building moneymakers (structures that give the player resources to build soldiers) and then sending an army to the middle of the map where a major base is. If the base is taken then the game is basically over at that point because it is such a strong chokepoint that becomes impenetrable. Once that base is taken then another army is sent to the base of their enemy and the game ends. This flaw in game design makes it that every game is basically the same and if you lose the middle base then your game is over and you might as well sit back and watch.

I am still recommending this game because it is not completed and there is a chance that the developers will change the layout of each map so that their is no stronghold in the middle that ends the game once taken. I am convinced that if that error is fixed then this game will become one of my new favourites.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Addiction in a small 400mb package that comes at no extra cost aside from the massive amount of time you will probably spend playing it.

Fun 1 v 1 or 2 v 2 or 3 v 3 level designs similar to starcraft combined with desert strike style gameplay along with a robotech / macross / battletech style land air mech.

There is even a single player skirmish survival and co-op if your'e tired of competition and a fairly deep unit design system allowing for lots of diversity in tactics.

If you enjoy games like starcraft but want even more challenge due to controlling your units + commanding your units, then try this one on for size you have nothin to lose!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

AirMech is a game that has a lot of potential. An Action Real Time Strategy game featuring transforming mechs, customizable loadouts with tons of different units? Sounds like a dream game.

The question is, is it a realistic dream? I think it is.

Let me start by saying AirMech has a very small playerbase right now compared to other Free to Play online games. This is not necessarily a bad thing, as the game is still fun when played versus bots.

The game has a bit of Pay to Win by having items be unlocked exclusively with in-game currency that can be purchase with real-life money, but the in-game currency is acquired at a pretty decent amount so you'll find yourself being able to buy two or three new units or a new pilot. The only thing you'll really find yourself grinding for is the ability to customize a mech, but all of the mechs are available at start to play as, just not to customize.

The gameplay is fun and fast paced and heavily strategy based. Based on which mech you use you'll find yourself playing the game quite differently. My personal favorite mech is the UFO, which has so little outgoing damage and so little damage reduction I don't even bother shooting most of the time. The fact that the games are exclusively 2v2 is understandable given the small playerbase, but it makes for a less action packed game than it could be for people who play as more strategy heavy mechs than pew pew heavy mechs.

The game has a lot of growing room, and I see it becoming very big if the game adjusts some of its.... Commercialistic... Aspects.

I personally don't mind that the game has a lot of things on sale, but it's a LOT of things on sale, and you're going to be flooded with them the moment you load up the game. If I want to buy something, I will, I promise, but honestly having giant ads for your in-game items flash before my eyes right when I load the game makes me not want to buy them.

The game is being constantly updated, though it seems that a lot of the updates are for things you have to buy. For a game in Beta, I feel this needs to be changed. Yeah, I understand that you need to put food on the table, but you're in the business of making a video game, which is also the business of making money. If your game is fun, and people enjoy it, the players will come and the money will flow in.

All in all, as it stands, I give AirMech a nice little 7/10. It's above average. It has a lot of potential it needs to expand on, and it has a bit of a money hungry attitude it needs to tone down on. Gameplay wise it's a fantastic Free to Play game that rewards the player for being good at the game. If you're considering giving it a try, there's no reason not to.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Recommended for a quick 5 minute game every now and then.

It's a fast-paced tower-defense-style action game with startegy elements. Each player(s) starts with a base.
Destroying the enemy base wins the game. Each base will produce units that automatically begin to roll towards the enemy base. On your way you will try to capture and hold neutral bases, that in return will allow you to produce more units in a shorter time.

The units can't be controlled by the player. Instead you control a transport plane. Your job is to pick up one or more of these units and deploy them either in a defensive slot near your base for defense, or drop them on the battle-field as reenforcements for your offense.

To support your units on the ground you may either try to shoot down the enemy's plane to keep him from deploying more troops. Or you land your craft, which then transforms into a mech"-style tank that can shoot enemy ground troops.

If you are shot down
recommended: during which you have to wait before being allowed to re-enter the battle-field.\n\nAs you win battles
hoursPlayed: you will be able to purchase other types of planes with special abilities and better ground units. However

column17: then look elsewhere."

If you like moba genre and, for one reason or another,you are tired of lol & dota you'll probably enjoy this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Few games can truly pull you into a moment from your childhood while simultaneously updating it with a completely new look and feel.  Airmech not only strives to do this for all the former Sega fans of the game Herzog Zwei, it does such an unbelievable job at it that will just leave you stunned.

Taking bits from the 'modern' game styles of Tower defenses with MOBAs and reaching into the RTS bucket a time or two, Airmech is an amazing mashup of each of these genres to find a fast paced birds-eye RTS style game while giving much of the focus to your 'hero' unit, the Airmech.  There isn't a lot new about the overall gameplay from the delicious early 90's game that was Herzog Zwei, but everything has had such loving attention to detail paid to it that it is obvious the designers spent as much time in the Sega world as I did, if not more!  The one new thing that IS included?  Oh so much customizaton.  Exactly what every online game needs.

In the original game, you were limited to one type of army and one 'airmech' (they look JUST like the default skin even, they just weren't called that then)  Carbon has just gone NUTS with this in the best way possible.  There are now numerous Airmech variants, each having distinct advantages and disadvantages over other Airmechs both through leveled abilities and innate stat differences.  Each variant posseses numerous skins offering no other bonuses other than the look of them, but are worth paying a few bucks to get if you are enjoying yourself.  I don't spend a lot of money on Free to Play games but Carbon has earned money out of me a few times simply by putting a smile on my face.

Army customization is through the roof as well.  In the source material there were like 9 or so units I believe?   Now there are a ton of options, I would say easily 3 to 4x that (I haven't taken the time to count but it's a lot).  If you have decided to support the project with your dollars you can even get special colors for your army or even use special units that are locked out of being used against people that don't have them, but CAN benefit them if you are playing Co-op.

There are a few different types of game modes.  They've recently added a challenges that I haven't really done much with and at launch will be adding a 'prime' campaign that I'm definitely eyeballing.  Currently you can go solo or co-op against AI opponents or engage in 1v1 to up to 3v3 PVP.

It would definitely be great to see more of these added in but I have to imagine this takes a lot of coding so I'd guess they are doing their best in this department, when I first found this game Prime wasn't a thing and the challenges were VERY barebones, so they definitely keep pushing more content in, just hope it keeps coming.  I'd throw maps in here as well.  While there are plenty of maps to keep you entertained for awhile, the nature of the game makes it quickly become VERY easy to exploit the AI, or just steamroll them on accident a lot of times.

So, should you play this game?  Well...  It's free, so yes.  You've got nothing to lose except the time it takes to try it out.  If it isn't for you, uninstall it and never come back, but more than likely you'll find yourself logging on repeatedly and tossing them some money so that you can really get the full experience.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Airmech

In the future, the last survivors of the Great War continue their fight with the ultimate war machine: the AirMech®. Created using lost technology, Pilots have found, salvaged, or stolen AirMechs that they use to protect the weak, or to pillage. Which side do you fight for? Airmech is a Action, Indie, Strategy Game which was released on the 8th November 2012 and as i said on my Aerena review, i am not into strategy games that much but i love this game ; It's so fun and so easy to play. Airmech is a fantastic game where you try and capture bases as well as defending your base from enemies.

Pros:
- Fantastic Gameplay
- Easy Controls
- Good Graphics

Cons:
- Some missions are hard

I would give this game a 9.5/10 because although i am a fan of this so far, if other people play it i would say that in some challenges, it will take you long to finish it, but otherwise this game is fantastic.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game is an insanely fun RTS with tons of different play styles. It has a great variety of troops to choose from and different mechs/pilots with special buffs to up your game. Another great feature is there is no penalty for leaving games (at least that i know of). Now for times like when you have an emergency or when your parents tell you turn it off you can still come back the next day and everything will be fine. There are a few cons though, one of them i majorly didnt like is there is no way of changing your mech type othere than a coupe classes and spending real money on skins. Speaking of real money, the whole game is very PTW. If you don't know what PTW means it means pay to win. It is very PTW because the game expects you to spend money on skins and in game currency to get that one new special item/buff you really want. Not only is there a lot of things that cost realmoney but they are also very overpriced. I guess that doesn't matter today because all games are now very expensiver and take a lot of devoting real tme and money to get good or better. Anyways i would definitly recommend checking out airmech it is a great game other than the PTW things.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

AirMech is a top-down Action real-time strategy game with its main concepts influenced by the old Herzog Zwei from 1989

Before giving a review of the game, I should elaborate on my taste in games as the reviewer. I like new ideas and new game mechanics, I prefer old classic strategy games over modern ones and I'm not very fond of the Free-to-play model in principle. I have been playing strategy games since the original Herzog Zwei in the very early 90s.

Game description  Core Gameplay Your play and control one of various mechs, where the default one is a jet fighter. What they all have in common is that the unit is directly controlled by you as in an arcade game. Compared to a normal" RTS game
date: this unit acts as your mouse cursor.\nWhen you are in the air as a jet/chinook/saucer you can pick up units
recommended: fly them off somewhere and place them where you want
hoursPlayed: as well as giving units different commands such as "hold ground" and "attack enemy base".\nWhen you transform into a mech you walk on the ground
voteText: can fire on ground targets and generally support your troops with different mech abilities.\nYou start with a home base where you can build units. The goal of the main game mode is to destroy the opponents base. In addition to the starting bases
helpfulPercent: the maps have outposts which can be taken over to earn resources faster
votesHelpful: in addition to act as recharge stations when your mech's health gets low or when you run out of energy.\nThe game matches are played 1vs1
votesTotal: 2vs2 or 3vs3 either in player-vs-player or player-vs-AI. A survival mode similar to tower-defense games lets up to 4 players defend a base against several incoming waves of enemy units.\nSince your opponent will be constantly fighting you over additional outposts as well as harassing your main base and your units
votesFunny: the game can become very hectic and fast-paced. The times you win
commentsCount: it feels very rewarding.\n\nCustomization OptionsThe game has tons of customization options. Where Herzog Zwei had around 8 different units
column16: AirMech has over 60 units. However
column17: you have to select a subset of these for your avatar character before starting a match
column18: and only 8 different units can be in your build menu at any time. In addition
column19:
your mech can be enhanced by various upgrades.
There are also cosmetic upgrades to make your mech and units stand out from the rest. Which brings us to..

Free-to-play profit modelThe game is free of charge
column20: which in of itself is amazing. I'm also happy to say that there aren't any balancing issues due to the profit model; the game is not "pay2win" as some people accuse free-to-play games of being. The company earns money on people buying the in-game currencies
column21: which is used to buy units
column22: mechs and upgrades in the game store. If you don't use your hard-earned cash however
column23: you get credits for just playing the game and meeting daylies. If you are familiar with Blizzards Hearthstone
column24: you know basically how it works. Someone who spend money on the game save themselves from maybe 4-6 hours of gameplay
column25: which is the time you would need to get the basic units. Other than that
column26: the things for sale are mostly cosmetics
column27:
such as a tank skin with a gothic look.

The Good
I love the main game mechanic! In RTS games such as Starcraft
column28: when you get over a certain skill level
column29: the game is won based on who can dish out the most commands to the most units in the least amount of time
column30: all else being equal.\nIn AirMech the mouse-clicking fest doesn't happen because unit commands are given via your mech
column31: and your mech is limited in how fast it can fly around. It gives people with not-so-great reflexes (hello me!) a fighting chance
column32: but still requires skill. It's just that AirMech requires a different skillset than RTSes like Starcraft and Command & Conquer. It's an RTS
column33: but also an arcade game.\n\nThe graphics style in the game is superb
column34: and my modest computer from 2011 plays the game at a decent framerate. I know that a lot of gamers like flashy graphics
column35: and the more realistic games look the better. If you're one of those
column36: you won't find that here. But AirMech doesn't try to look realistic. Rather
column37: the developers went for a more cartoon-like look with very colorful scenes. I prefer game graphics which decides for a certain art style
column38: rather than games that adds all sorts of HDR lighting
column39: blooming and depth-of-field.\n\nThe whole game interface is really well made. Menus are sharp and descriptive. After logging in
column40: you'll see a chat window where you can talk to other players
column41:
find opponents or people to play coop with. The community seems very friendly towards beginners.

The Bad
This is mostly nitpicking
column42: however there are some things that goes against my personal preferences.\n\nWhile the overall artistic style of the game is great
column43: some of the abilities or unit skins you can get are just strangely out of place graphics-wise. The "boomer" unit can be made to look like a Creeper from Minecraft. That doesn't fit the game at all! The overall style of the game is a kind of post-apocalyptic future where mechs control the earth
column44: but here you have creepers in the battlefield
column45: and mech abilities in the form of witches on brooms? If other players like it
column47: but it would be nice to be able to turn it off or be able to choose default skins/models for all players that are more consistent.\n\nAs the game is in the free-to-play category
column48: the developer/publisher needs to make money somehow. And that brings me to annoying attention-grabbing and nagging. Whenever I start the game and enter the main menu / lobby
column49: the game nags me to give referral links to friends (basically free promotion) and get in-game currency in return. In addition
column50: the game highlights the store icon and your current credits sometimes
column51: and hints you to spend your credits and buy more in subtle and not so subtle ways. This is incredibly annoying! I'd like to focus on playing the game
column52: not get nagged on to spend money and treated like a walking wallet. Even if a game is free to play
column53:
it should be possible to turn off all the stuff which distracts you from the main game.
Note that the actual game matches are void of this problem. It's only in the main menu/lobby.

Herzog Zwei which this game is influenced by was great because of its game mechanics and its simplicity. But the free-to-play model is incompatible with simplicity. The end result is that the number of units and items in AirMech is inflated quite a bit. It might sounds strange that more choice and customization could be considered a bad thing
column54: but here it is. The game would be vastly better by less choice and complexity
column55:
but I suppose the publisher would be making less money that way.

Verdict
Despite the nitpicking above
column56: AirMech is incredibly fun to play. And it has something for everyone
column57: whether you are a hardcore competitive RTS player or a casual gamer. Play PvP ranked if you enjoy competitive play
column58: or team up with other players against the AI otherwise.\nYou can use mouse+keyboard or an Xbox 360 joypad
column59: and getting into a match takes seconds. A match lasts for between 10 and 20 minutes
column60: so you have time to play in your lunch break if that's your thing. The strategy and tactics in the game can be incredibly deep depending on the experience of the players
column61: and no two rounds are the same.\nThe game's presentation suffers a bit from the free-to-play market model and it would be nice to be able to pay once to get rid of the "give me more money!" nagging
column62: but nothing is perfect. And again
column63: the game does *not* give paying players any advantage.\n\nI give AirMech 7.5 out of 10. It's free! At least install it and give it a try."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm not a fan of MOBAs at all but i'm in love with this game. Fast-paced and easy to pick up, but it's not very popular unfortunately. At most, there will be 2-3 games up at once and lobby hosts can be very picky with who joins a game. I understand that they probably want to play with friends, but if that's the case, set up a private lobby instead of kicking non-friends as soon as they join the server.

Match-making is also a problem, as you get paired up with people either below or out of your skill range. Very rarely will I find someone who's right around my level, but that's if I even find someone else. Match-making can take long periods of time, and I always find myself going to the custom game lobby before Match-making finds someone, since I actually have a chance at joining a game there.

One thing I do find rather irritating is the fact that there are some Diamonds (In-game premium currency) that I don't have access to unless I upgrade to Silver status. I've already unlocked them, I just can't use them, which really doesn't make much sense to me. Seeing the Diamonds I COULD have by upgrading makes me feel gipped by the game. What sense does it make to lock something that someone has legitimately earned? I understand that as a F2P game, certain restrictions must be put in place to ensure that a profit is made, but plenty of people buy enough Diamonds to do more than sustain this game. Other than that, I have no qualms about the Cash Shop/premium currency.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you love DoTA and real time strategy/real time tactics game (Age of Empire, Command and Conquer, Empire at War, Battle Realms), you would love this one.

This game is a perfect hybrid between action/MOBA game and RTS/RTC game; putting MOBA first, RTS/RTC second.

AirMech is easier to get start with than DoTA. I personally had to familiarize myself with DoTA for much longer time than with this game. It plays as the usual MOBA game, but with a twist: you gain control of one hero, and there's also the usual creep, but not only that, you can build units to support you in battle. And along the way you have to gain control of neutral and enemy buildings, where you could take your units from there (just like RTS/RTC game), before you crush the enemy's HQ.

There's almost no pay to win elements in this game. Most of the stuff are buyable with in-game cash, even the cosmetics. There are a few units and additional bonus which may need a bit grinding though. The maps are enough to pose different challenges.

I can't find any big downside in this game except maybe for the AI difficulties. The first three difficulties (Trainer"
hoursPlayed: but beyond that it could be extremely frustrating. Especially if they start to spam you with tanks. That's almost unstoppable.\n\n8.5/10. Play this game with friends or random strangers. The size is only about 600 MB - worth to try!"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Awesome game. This is an Action-RTS game. Do battle on a map for control, supply and position. You can give your units orders like defend, attack, follow - but you don't micro manage them. Instead you control (WASD) the airmech commander unit which is much more powerful than the typical unit on the map. You can support your troops in battle from either land or the air in your transforming mech. In air mode you can pick-up and transport units quickly around the map for well-timed assaults on control points. Airmechs come into each battle with a load-out which determines the units they can build, their abilities, various buffs - as well as cosmetic aspects. If you are playing multiplayer 2v2 or more, then you'll have other airmech teammates and you can synergize your choice of airmech and loadout. Some airmechs are better suited for fast build times, or defensive strategies, while others are better utilized by being in the thick of combat.

This game has an excellent tutorial and introduces the game with solo-played challenges which teach the basic concepts then allows you to practice them until your confident enough to start playing any number of the standard game modes on offer. Solo or coop survival mode where you attempt to survive waves of enemy units, or 2v2, 3v3 multiplayer vs other players. The various modes keep the game fun both for casual players who want to play coop and more competitive players who want match-making ranked competitve play.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This Game Is Great!
So you like DoTA? And the LoLs? Well, I have a new game for you. Play AirMech, it's free! You can have fun for free, and you don't have to pay a penny for anything! You can if you want to, however, and get more virtual currency. This game has the world's greatest range of units I've seen in a while. You can fight people in insane robot dogfights, with easy to learn, hard to master controls! Here's a list of my 5 favorite things from Airmech.

You can meet new people!
The astounding community!
Stars. You'll figure it out if you play. Or look up Airmech Stars or something XP
The fun dogfighting style of gameplay.
The fun collectibles and pets!

The End!
If you want to refer me or commend me my username is ShaoQuinn!
voteText: 6 of 12 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nStrategic combat mixed in with the constant challenge of controlling the map. You get to pick from a variety of Airmechs(after unlocking/buying them with in-game currency[Kudos]), all with special abilities. After that, pick a pilot, customize your Airmech with different parts, pick your units, pets, and Guardians, and then engage in an epic high action battle between you(and possibly a partner, CPU or a real human) and your adversary(ies), which again can be CPU or another player. In-game purchases using real money are far from necessary and it's not that difficult to progress. If you want to look a little classier, spend a couple bucks. If you just wanna have some fun, keep your money. In my honest opinion, this is the best free-to-play game on Steam.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Sorry for my English. Again. I am not from English-speaking country.

This game is good, it has low system requirements, interesting gameplay and it sounds wierd ('cause MOBA became from RTS), but it is something like MOBA+RTS+Shooter (not an FPS, but the shooter). It has all the best things from all the genres, but the worst things from F2P games. But let start my review from positive sides of this game, and there are a lot of it.

You know, it is something medium between MOBA and RTS: you control only one unit and you can't control others (like in MOBA), but you can buy units and tell 'em what do they need to do (like in RTS). But the part from shooting is the best - now you don't need to target the unit, you just need to shoot in them! The gameplay is not just about destroying towers & base, I mean you need to destroy the base, but you don't need to destroy towers (here they are actually other little bases), but you need to capture them. From the beginning, you theese bases are holden by neutral units, that are actually hard to destroy. There are a lot of maps to play so you will never be bored. And the best part of this game is main units you controll. They are actually transformers: flying like planes and walking robots. They have different skills and they're really balanced. Also, there are no roles and no artefacts so it is not so good part of this game but it still fun. There are not so much of mechs, you unlock it by leveling up and buying, but they're really cheap, so basicly leveling up is enough. You get a lot of kudos (in-game money in this games) and exp for even a match with bots, there are also VIP to get a double kudos n' exp, but it is useless. There are units to buy (also by leveling up and a little of kudos), characters (unlocking them is exactly the same) and some other features. But there are also one more way than VIP to get more kudos with exp and it's free: just build some structures in non-match base in game menu and you will get some % of extra currency or a wheat field where you can sell wheat for kudos (so you don't need to be nerd to unlock something in this game). Match continues 20-40 minutes, but I think it isn't the limit or minimum. But now let's talk about one con, but the big one.

The game has got some kinda imbalance between novice, nerd and donater. There are diamond currency and it is real money currency, but you can get something from missions. Good thing is that mechs you can purchase by theese diamonds are only the skins which aren't better than free (the only thing you can purchase 'em with any level). But there are ultimate" units and characters that haven't got level limit and they are powerfuller than free ones

hoursPlayed: but not buyable in the match
voteText: you buy 'em in game

votesHelpful: balance in this game isn't as ♥♥♥♥ed up as in ♥♥♥♥♥♥ MOBAs like Prime World or Panzar.\n\nI reccomend this game
votesTotal: one of the best MOBAs in the MOBA market
votesFunny: and yes
commentsCount: I think it's MOBA
column16: not the RTS 'cause you control one unit

column18: etc. It's MOBA with parts of RTS and Shooter. Enjoy it!"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Although the game looked cool on paper and at the first day, that was because I was just messing with challanges and bots.

(info: I live on Brasil, South America)
When it came to play it 'for real', the ping/freezing was terrible. I was only being matched with people from North America for some reason... And that was some days ago. On the next day, the BR(only SA server btw) was down, still was until last time I checked. Which means I can't even play online, for how much it could work...

Also, on the first day I was messing around playing it with a gamepad. The UI kept bugging, sometimes only the mouse worked(badly), sometimes only the controller, and many times the game became unresponsive to input.
OK, let's play it KB+M.
Nope, annoying mouse smoothing attacks!


Really guys, this looked cool, but these bugs make it un-playabe for me and surely others in areas relatively far from a server. Or maybe anyone in SA too .-.
